title: Around the Valley : Parkland graduate Kyle Stinner gets new position with Lehigh softball
body_text:
The late Ed Stinner and Lehigh softball coach Fran Troyan were good friends.
When Stinner was the coach at Allen, several of his players went to Lehigh to play for Troyan and his wife, Sue, who was the previous Mountain Hawks head coach.
Kim Miller, Nina Rems and Mandee Wessner, who were all members of Stinner’s 1990 state championship team at Allen, also played at Lehigh where they enjoyed even more success.
Stinner and Troyan worked camps together and Stinner nearly went to Lehigh to join the staff, but his heart was dedicated to the players at the youth level and high school players in the Lehigh Valley, particularly at Parkland and Whitehall where he coached as an assistant after resigning at Allen.
But Kyle Stinner, Ed’s son, learned a lot about coaching from his father and also inherited his love of softball. It’s a family tradition since his mom, Melodie, played softball and his sister, Deanna, pitched Parkland to a state title in 2009 and played Division I softball at Temple.
Kyle Stinner was a great addition to Troyan’s staff for several years, and enjoyed his time but the travel was a bit too demanding.
But now he’s back at Lehigh and his father, who died in September at the age of 71, is surely looking down from above with great pride.
Stinner has been announced as Lehigh softball’s director of program development and will serve the program in an administrative and analytics-based leadership role.
In his new role, Stinner will focus on analytics, technology integration, recruiting support and overall program building.
“Kyle is incredibly bright, able and a longtime fan of Lehigh softball,” Troyan said in a release. “Having someone who understands our culture and values, while also bringing a strong analytical mindset, gives us a real competitive advantage. His work this spring will help us edify and build our program in ways that will benefit Lehigh softball student-athletes immediately and for years to come.”
Sinner’s return, the release said, reinforces Lehigh’s commitment to innovation, development and sustained success on and off the field.
Troyan begins his 31st season on Feb. 6 against Texas A&M-Corpus Christi in the Felsberg Invitational in Miami. He has an all-time record of 965-550-8 and has gone 413-97 in the Patriot League. His teams have won 19 Patriot League regular-season titles, 12 tournament titles and have made 11 NCAA tournament appearances.
The Mountain Hawks are coming off a 28-24 season. This year’s team will feature Maia D’Amico, a first-year player from Freedom.
Troyan’s coaching staff includes Freedom High graduate Marisa DeStasio, who played at Binghamton for four years and then became a head coach at Muhlenberg College for six seasons and was an assistant at Lafayette for three years. She is in her second year on the Lehigh staff.
The staff also includes third-year pitching coach Dani Gonzales, who was a standout pitcher at Saint Joseph’s and then became an assistant coach at Penn for 11 seasons and was the interim head coach in 2023.
Rounding out the staff is Fran and Sue’s son David Troyan, who is entering his fourth season with the team and will be the sports performance coach after working as a volunteer assistant the last three years. David Troyan is also a Division I women’s basketball referee.
Notre Dame-Green Pond Hall of Fame
The Hall of Fame ceremonies have been coming at a fast pace during the boys basketball season. Notre Dame-Green Pond held its ceremony on Jan. 10.
The new inductees included:
Cheryl (Muller) Fenton: A member of the class of 1975, Fenton has coached cheerleading at the school for 33 years with a one-year stint in 1984-85 and then since 1994. She was a Colonial League coach of the year seven times. She has coached more than 1,100 cheerleaders and attended more than 1,300 games. She has spent more than 15,000 hours at practices and games. Her team won the 2004-2005 Elite Camp championship. Many of her girls have gone on to compete at the collegiate level, including Division I schools such as Virginia Tech, Seton Hall and Penn State.
Frank Scattene: A member of the class of 1976, Scattene played football and was an Express-Times and Centennial League first-team running back. He ran for 1,180 yards as a senior. He started in the LARC All-Star Classic and was the school’s scholar-athlete representative to the National Football Foundation’s Lehigh Valley Chapter. In basketball, he was a three-year letterwinner and was a Centennial League second-team all-star and an honorable mention choice on the Express-Times All-Area team. He also was a letterwinner on the school’s first volleyball team. He currently leads the stat crew for Lehigh University football games at Goodman Stadium.
Scott Salabsky: A member of the class of 1994, Salabsky finished his career with 105 career wrestling wins. He finished fifth in the state in both 1993 and ’94. He was a four-time Centennial League champion and a District 11 runner-up in 1993 and a district champ in 1994. As a junior, he participated for Talon Club USA against Russia and was in the Challenge of Champions in 1994. He was the school’s male athlete of the year as a senior and a Lehigh Valley Scholar-Athlete of the Year finalist in 1994.
Maura (Delserro) Hammerstone: A member of the class of 1995, Hammerstone was the school’s cross-country MVP three times. She was second in the Centennial League meet and third in District 11 as a sophomore in 1992 and won the Centennial League title as a junior. In her senior year, she finished fifth in the Colonial League meet.
Chadd Lilly: A member of the class of 2005, Lilly scored 1,099 career points and was the Colonial League MVP in 2005 and was also the Express-Times player of the year and third-team all-state in Class 2A. He was also a first-team Colonial League all-star selection in both 2003 and ’05.
Schedule update
Several area boys basketball games were played on Tuesday as scholastic life slowly gets back to normal after Sunday’s storm, including Allentown Central Catholic-Parkland, Liberty-Easton, and Bethlehem Catholic-Freedom in the Eastern Pennsylvania Conference and Notre Dame-GP-Southern Lehigh in the Colonial League. Many other games were postponed.
Wednesday night’s busy card now features Northern Lehigh at Lehighton, Emmaus at Dieruff, Jim Thorpe at Northwestern Lehigh, East Stroudsburg South at Pocono Mountain East, Scranton Prep at Pocono Mountain West, Catasauqua at Saucon Valley, Salisbury at Southern Lehigh, Whitehall at Allen and Pen Argyl at Wilson Area.
The big one between Northampton and Nazareth was moved to Thursday night at Ray Nunamaker Gym. Also on Thursday, Bangor is at Catasauqua, Allen is at Lincoln Leadership, Moravian Academy is at Notre Dame-Green Pond, Northwestern Lehigh is at Palmerton and Pocono Mountain West visits Pleasant Valley.
There is one unique afternoon game on Thursday as Wilson Area faces Fleetwood in a nonleague contest at the home of the 76ers and Flyers, Xfinity Mobile Arena in Philadelphia. The Warriors and Tigers meet at 1:05 p.m.
